column1: Polanco is an affluent neighborhood in the Miguel Hidalgo borough of Mexico City. Polanco is an upscale community
column2: famed for its luxury shopping on Avenida Presidente Masaryk
column3: one of the most expensive streets in the Americas
column4: as well as for the numerous prominent cultural institutions located within the neighborhood
column5: such as the Museo Soumaya and the Colección Jumex. Polanco is often called the "Beverly Hills of Mexico"
column6: having one of the country's densest concentrations of luxury shopping
column7: with the most Michelin star restaurants
column10: and diplomatic missions and embassies. Additionally
column11: it is one of the most desirable real estate markets in Latin America.

column1: The colony takes its name from a river that crossed what is now the Avenue Campos Elisios (Champs Elysees)
column2: named in memory of the Spanish Jesuit Juan Alfonso de Polanco
column3: a secretary of Ignatius of Loyola
column6: were members of board of the Kings of Spain in the 17th century and came to Mexico as officers of the Crown.

column1: In a plan made by Francisco Antonio Guerrero y Torres and dated 1784
column2: a "ruined house Polanco" is located on the grounds of the Hacienda de San Juan de los Morales. This hacienda sits on land donated in the sixteenth century to Hernán Cortés by the King of Spain
column3: under the jurisdiction of Tacuba. At the beginning of the colonial times
column4: parts of this land (near the current center of the Hacienda) were occupied for planting mulberry trees for breeding silkworms (hence the name "los morales"). The hull of the Hacienda as currently known dates from the eighteenth century. Extension lands belonging to the estate began to be divided in the late 1920s.

column1: Polanco was developed in 1937 by the Aleman family

column5: the entrance to the new neighborhood marked by a tile obelisk facing Reforma. In those days
column6: there were only mansions surrounded by gardens and tree lined streets.

column1: Polanco enjoyed a construction boom in the 1950s
column2: when mansions and luxury apartment complexes were built. The style of construction of most mansions of this period is "Colonial Californiano"
column3: inspired by the Mission Revival Style in the Southwestern United States
column5: front-side gardens and inside halls. Some of these mansions have been renovated and converted into businesses and restaurants; many others have simply been torn down and replaced with new buildings.

column2: many of them being Michelin star-rated.

column1: Polanco is served by the Polanco and Auditorio stations of the Mexico City metro (subway). The western terminus of the double decker buses of the Reforma line of the Metrobús (bus rapid transit) is in Polanco. Peseros (minibuses)
column2: city buses and trolleybuses ply numerous streets in Polanco continuing to and from other parts of the city.
